# Assignment based on entrance score

```{r tutoring-running, fig.height=5.25, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(broom)
library(kableExtra)
library(scales)
library(patchwork)
library(latex2exp)
library(rdrobust)
library(rddensity)

# Fake program data
set.seed(1234)
num_students <- 1000
tutoring <- tibble(
  id = 1:num_students,
  entrance_exam = rbeta(num_students, shape1 = 7, shape2 = 2),
  exit_exam = rbeta(num_students, shape1 = 5, shape2 = 3)
) %>% 
  mutate(entrance_exam = entrance_exam * 100,
         tutoring = entrance_exam <= 70) %>% 
  mutate(exit_exam = exit_exam * 40 + 10 * tutoring + entrance_exam / 2) %>% 
  mutate(tutoring_fuzzy = ifelse(entrance_exam > 60 & entrance_exam < 80,
                                 sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), n(), replace = TRUE),
                                 tutoring)) %>% 
  mutate(tutoring_text = factor(tutoring, levels = c(FALSE, TRUE),
                                labels = c("No tutor", "Tutor")),
         tutoring_fuzzy_text = factor(tutoring_fuzzy, levels = c(FALSE, TRUE),
                                      labels = c("No tutor", "Tutor"))) %>% 
  mutate(entrance_centered = entrance_exam - 70)

ggplot(tutoring, aes(x = entrance_exam, y = tutoring_text, fill = tutoring_text)) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 70, size = 2, color = "#FFDC00") + 
  geom_point(size = 5, pch = 21, color = "white", alpha = 0.7,
             position = position_jitter(width = 0, height = 0.2, seed = 1234)) + 
  labs(x = "Entrance exam score", y = NULL) + 
  guides(fill = FALSE) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#900DA4", "#F89441"), name = NULL) +
  theme_bw(base_size = 28, base_family = "Fira Sans Condensed")
```

```{r tutoring-outcome-edlta, fig.height=5.25, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
rdd_tutoring <- lm(exit_exam ~ entrance_centered + tutoring, data = tutoring) %>% 
  tidy()
effect_control <- filter(rdd_tutoring, term == "(Intercept)")$estimate
late <- filter(rdd_tutoring, term == "tutoringTRUE")$estimate
effect_treatment <- effect_control + late
ggplot(tutoring, aes(x = entrance_exam, y = exit_exam, fill = tutoring_text, color = tutoring_text)) +
  geom_point(size = 4, pch = 21, color = "white", alpha = 0.25) +

              method = "lm", size = 2, show.legend = FALSE) +
  ggplot2::annotate(geom = "segment", x = 70, xend = 70, 
           y = effect_control, yend = effect_treatment,
```

# Behind the scenes of RDs

- Basically, regression discontinuities work under an **.darkorange[asymptotic assumption]**:

--

- Let $Y_i$ be the outcome of interest, $Z_i$ the treatment assignment, $R_i$ the running variable, and $c$ the cutoff score:

$$Z_i =   \left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
      0 & R_i\leq c \\
      1 & R_i>c \\
\end{array} 
\right.$$

--

- Then, we can define the treatment effect $\delta$ as:

$$\delta = \lim_{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^+}E[Y_i| R_i = c + \epsilon] - \lim_{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^-}E[Y_i| R_i = c + \epsilon]$$

# Conditions required for identification
--

- Threshold rule **.darkorange[exists]** and cutoff point is **.darkorange[known]**

--

- The running variable $R_i$ is **.darkorange[continuous]** near $c$.

--

- Key assumption:

.box-5LA[Continuity of E[Y(1)|R] and E[Y(0)|R] at R=c]

# Potential outcomes need to be smooth across the threshold

```{r po-smooth, fig.height=5.25, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
# Fake program data
set.seed(1234)
num_students <- 1000
tutoring <- tibble(
  id = 1:num_students,
  entrance_exam = rbeta(num_students, shape1 = 7, shape2 = 2),
  exit_exam = rbeta(num_students, shape1 = 5, shape2 = 3)
) %>% 
  mutate(entrance_exam = entrance_exam * 100,
         tutoring = entrance_exam <= 70) %>% 
  mutate(po = exit_exam * 40 + entrance_exam / 2,
    exit_exam = exit_exam * 40 + 10 * tutoring + entrance_exam / 2) %>% 
  mutate(tutoring_fuzzy = ifelse(entrance_exam > 60 & entrance_exam < 80,
                                 sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), n(), replace = TRUE),
                                 tutoring)) %>% 
  mutate(tutoring_text = factor(tutoring, levels = c(FALSE, TRUE),
                                labels = c("No tutor", "Tutor")),
         tutoring_fuzzy_text = factor(tutoring_fuzzy, levels = c(FALSE, TRUE),
                                      labels = c("No tutor", "Tutor"))) %>% 
  mutate(entrance_centered = entrance_exam - 70)

tutoring$exit_exam[tutoring$entrance_exam>70] = tutoring$exit_exam[tutoring$entrance_exam>70] + 25
#tutoring$po = tutoring$po + 25

ggplot(tutoring, aes(x = entrance_exam, y = exit_exam, fill = tutoring_text, color = tutoring_text)) +
  geom_point(size = 4, pch = 21, color = "white", alpha = 0.25) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 70, size = 2, color = "#FFDC00") + 
  geom_smooth(data = filter(tutoring, entrance_exam <= 70),
              method = "loess", size = 2, show.legend = FALSE) +
  geom_smooth(data = filter(tutoring, entrance_exam > 70),
              method = "loess", size = 2, show.legend = FALSE) +
  
  geom_smooth(data = filter(tutoring, entrance_exam <= 70), aes(x = entrance_exam, y = po + 25),
              method = "loess", se = FALSE, lty = 2,size = 2, show.legend = FALSE, color = "#900DA4") +
  geom_smooth(data = filter(tutoring, entrance_exam > 70),aes(x = entrance_exam, y = po + 10),
              method = "loess", size = 2, se = FALSE, lty = 2, show.legend = FALSE, color = "#F89441") +
  
  labs(x = "Running Variable", y = "Outcome") + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#900DA4", "#F89441"), name = NULL) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#900DA4", "#F89441")) +
  theme_bw(base_size = 28, base_family = "Fira Sans Condensed") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc() +
  #guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, override.aes = list(alpha = 1)), color = FALSE) +
        #axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_blank(),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_blank(),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# How do we actually estimate an RD?

- The simplest way to do this is to fit a regression:

$$Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1(R_i-c) + \beta_2\mathrm{I}[R_i>c] + \beta_3(R_i-c)\mathrm{I}[R_i> c]$$

---
# How do we actually estimate an RD?

- The simplest way to do this is to fit a regression:

$$Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1\color{#900DA4}{\underbrace{(R_i-c)}_\text{Distance to the cutoff}} + \beta_2\mathrm{I}[R_i>c] + \beta_3\color{#900DA4}{\overbrace{(R_i-c)}^\text{Distance to the cutoff}}\mathrm{I}[R_i> c]$$
---
# How do we actually estimate an RD?

- The simplest way to do this is to fit a regression:

$$Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1(R_i-c) + \beta_2\color{#F89441}{\underbrace{\mathrm{I}[R_i>c]}_\text{Treatment}} + \beta_3(R_i-c)\color{#F89441}{\overbrace{\mathrm{I}[R_i> c]}^\text{Treatment}}$$
--

- You want to add **.darkorange[flexibility]** for each side of the cutoff.

--

# We can be more flexible

- The previous example just included linear terms, but you can also be more flexible:


$$Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1f(R_i-c) + \beta_2\mathrm{I}[R_i>c] + \beta_3f(R_i-c)\mathrm{I}[R_i> c]$$

   - Where $f$ is any function you want.
   
---
# What happens if we fit a quadratic model?
```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
lm(sales ~ dist + I(dist^2) + treat + dist*treat + treat*I(dist^2), data = sales)
```

```{r rd_quad, fig.height=4, fig.width=8, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}

lm2 <- lm(sales ~ dist + I(dist^2) + treat + dist*treat + treat*I(dist^2), data = sales)
options(scipen = 0)
sales_aug <- broom::augment(lm2, data = sales)

ggplot(data = sales_aug, aes(x = time, y = sales)) +
  geom_point(size = 5, pch = 21, color = "white", fill="grey") +
  geom_line(data = filter(sales_aug, time>c), aes(x = time, y = .fitted), color = "#F89441", lwd = 2) +
  geom_line(data = filter(sales_aug, time<=c), aes(x = time, y = .fitted), color = "#900DA4", lwd = 2) +
  theme_ipsum_fsc() +
  #guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, override.aes = list(alpha = 1)), color = FALSE) +
        #axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Potential problems

- There are **.darkorange[many potential problems]** with the previous examples:

  - Which polynomial function should we choose? Linear, quadratic, other?
  
  - What bandwidth should we choose? Whole sample? [-100,100]?

# Package `rdrobust`

- Robust Regression Discontinuity introduced by Cattaneo, Calonico, Farrell & Titiunik (2014).

- Use of **.darkorange[local polynomial]** for fit.

- **.darkorange[Data-driven optimal bandwidth]** (bias vs variance).

--

- `rdrobust`: Estimation of LATE and opt. bandwidth

- `rdplot`: Plotting RD with nonparametric local polynomial.

---
# Let's compare with previous parametric results

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
rdplot(y = sales$sales, x = sales$time, c = c, 
       title = "RD plot", x.label = "time", y.label = "sales")
```

```{r rdplot, fig.height=4.5, fig.width=8, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(rdrobust)

c = min(sales$time[sales$treat==0])

rdplot(y = sales$sales, x = sales$time, c = c, title = "RD plot",
       x.label = "time", y.label = "sales", col.dots = "#F89441", col.lines = "#900DA4")
```

# How do we weight observations?

- `rdrobust` uses `rdbwselect()` function (by default) to estimate a data-driven bandwidth (i.e. what observations we are going to use for estimation).

  - If we use a bandwidth, does this mean that the RD is estimating an effect for that population within the bandwidth?
  
--

- **.darkorange[Kernels]** are also important in this context:

  - How do I weight observations within the bandwidth (e.g. uniform, triangle)
  
---
# Observing kernels

```{r kernels, fig.height=6, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}

data <- data.frame(u = c(0,0,1,1,1,1,1,0,0),
                   t = c(0,0,0,0.5,1,0.5,0,0,0),
                   r = c(-3,-2,-2,-1,0,1,2,2,3))

g1 <- ggplot(data = data, aes(x = r, y = u)) +
  geom_line(color = "#F89441", lwd = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = -2.05), lwd = 1.5, color = "#E16462", lty = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 2.05), lwd = 1.5, color = "#E16462", lty = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 0), lwd = 1.2, color = "dark grey", lty = 2) +
  theme_ipsum_fsc() +
  xlab("Running variable") + ylab("Weights") + ggtitle("Uniform Kernel") + 
  #guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, override.aes = list(alpha = 1)), color = FALSE) +
        #axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g2 <- ggplot(data = data, aes(x = r, y = t)) +
  geom_line(color = "#F89441", lwd = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = -2), lwd = 1.5, color = "#E16462", lty = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 2), lwd = 1.5, color = "#E16462", lty = 2) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = 0), lwd = 1.2, color = "dark grey", lty = 2) +
  theme_ipsum_fsc() +
  xlab("Running variable") + ylab("Weights") + ggtitle("Triangle Kernel") + 
  #guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, override.aes = list(alpha = 1)), color = FALSE) +
        #axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g1 + g2
```

# Takeaway points

.pull-left[
- RD designs are **.darkorange[great]** for causal inference!

  - Strong internal validity
  - Number of robustness checks
  
- **.darkorange[Limited]** external validity.

- Make sure to check your data:

  - Discontinuity in treatment assignment
  - Density across the cutoff
  - Smoothness of covariates
]
